packagedElement.name: Cash Management And Account Services BOM SD

ownedComment.body: Specification of how a service arrangement can be fulfilled.

An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.
Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services
The fulfillment of a service arrangement.
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
A service offered as a feature of a product.

A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
Directions on how the selected payment mechanism would be used; E.g. what service level (instant payment or not...), e.g. what intermediate correspondents should be used...

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.
The role of an account in a payment instruction
The specific role that a specific party has in a specific payment instruction
The role of an account in a transaction
The meaning of a time indication for an object; E.g. opening data of an account, signing date of an agreement... birth date of a person.
A point in time. Can be a period, a date or a more detailed time indication.
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts
Money Transfer instruction given to a Payment Service Provider
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
An arrangement which specifies the promise to offer the payment service, accompanied by the payment modalities.
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts

An exposed function (an externalized functionality) that is able to deliver a certain value/benefit (a proposed definition adapted from Archimate).
A unit of functionality that a system exposes to its environment, while hiding internal operations, which provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise).
Comment:
A Service is something that is done by an actor for the benefit of an actor in the environment.
A system is the broad sense of the word. Means Business Service, Application Service, Technology Service, "huppeldepup" Service
Characteristics of a service:
A system (The Service Domain) Functionality is exposed (Action Term) It provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise)
Exposing functionality means that the internals of realizing the service is hidden for the beneficiary of the Service.
In BIAN a "Service Operation" is visualized as a "Business Service" , the "System" refers to the "Service Domain"
The name of a Service Operation is composed of an "Action Term" + "Subject Matter" which is the "Control Record" or the "Behaviour Qualifier".
Service is the intangible equivalent of a good. (ISO20022).
A type of economic activity that is intangible, is not stored and does not result in ownership; a service is consumed at the point of sale (FIBO & Business Dictionary)

An act, initiated by the payer or payee, of placing, transferring or withdrawing funds, irrespective of any underlying obligations between the payer and payee (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from PSD)
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee

An obligation to do the payment.
Obligation for the debtor to pay the creditor an amount of cash. (ISO20022)
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
Instruction to pay an amount of money to an ultimate beneficiary, on behalf of an originator. (ISO20022)
A request to do something.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.

A selection of interest product feature modalities for a specific interestment arrangement in a specific agreemen
The specification of the set of parameters used to calculate an interest amount. (adapted from ISO20022)
An arrangement into which both parties confirm on an interest product feature.
A product feature that is specifying the interest feature applicable in the product
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
A request to do something.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.
An Interest Modality applicable to a Interest Product Feature

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.

Entry means Posting to an account that results in an increase or decrease to a balance. (ISO20022)
An entry posted/booked in the account.
Consideration, such as amount of money, paid or received in exchange for an asset that has been invested, loaned or borrowed for a certain period. (ISO20022)
The way in which an interest feature can be applied
a distinctive attribute or aspect of something.
Something that happens, has happened, can happen or is planned to happen.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.

Arrangement in which funds are transferred from one deposit account to another when a certain threshold is reached.
Banking arrangement in which a checking (current) account balance above or below a certain amount is automatically transferred to and from an interest-bearing (savings or money market fund) account. The objective of a sweep account is to maximize the accountholder's interest earnings while covering all withdrawals. (Business Dictionary)
Sweep Account is a brokerage account whose cash balance is automatically transferred into an interest-bearing investment, such as a money market fund. (Investorwords)
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee
Execution of the sweep arrangement
A feature, often offered in a Savings/Current Account product that allows (to link the fixed term deposits with the current or savings account) .....should be checked?
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
A Fee Modality applicable to a Fee Product Feature
A selection of Fee Product Feature modalities for a specific fee arrangement in a specific agreement
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
A product feature that is specifying the fee feature applicable in the product
Party who plays a specific rule in a specific fee arrangement.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
A request to do something.
A transaction that changes the financial position (the status of the finances) of involved party.

A financial transaction that is the result of fulfillment of a fee arrangement
Example: - the calculation of fee - the charge of fee as a debt - the payment of fee
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.

A financial instruction to fulfill a fee arrangement
Example: - Instruction to calculate the fee - Instruction to charge the calculated fee - Instruction to book the calculated fee

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.

Entry means Posting to an account that results in an increase or decrease to a balance. (ISO20022)
An entry posted/booked in the account.
The way in which a fee or charge can be applied for a service.
A charge for services rendered.
a distinctive attribute or aspect of something.
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
Restriction on capability or operations allowed. (ISO20022)

to do: definitie opzoeken
A statement of account is a detailed report of the contents of an account. (AccountingTool)

A unit of an organisation that does not have legal standing outside the organisation.
A logical element or segment of a company (such as accounting, production, marketing) representing a specific business function, and a definite place on the organizational chart, under the domain of a manager. Also called department, division, or a functional area. (Business Dictionary)
Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/business-unit.html

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)

If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.
The involvement (role) of an instance of a party in an instance of an account.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.

Entry means Posting to an account that results in an increase or decrease to a balance. (ISO20022)
An entry posted/booked in the account.
The counted state (e.g., the amount of money, the value, the number) of something - It is the sum of entries - It is the derived attribute - It is an information object

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
The position of account at the certain point of time.
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. A formal or informal common understanding between two or more (legal competent) parties concerning one or more subject matters expressed in a set of arrangements, terms and conditions. (adapted from Legal System and FIBO)
A duty that is specified in and imposed by an agreement. (FIBO)
A contingent right conferred via an agreement. (FIBO)

An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.
Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services
The involvement (role) of an instance of a party in an instance of an arrangement.
Specification of how a service arrangement can be fulfilled.
Something that happens, has happened, can happen or is planned to happen.

Right or obligation linked to the involvement of a party in an agreement
Can be default, linked to an involvement type, or specifically agreed upon. This can be default obligations or entitlements, of specific arrangements
A Service Modality applicable to a Service Feature
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
A service offered as a feature of a product.
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
A request to do something.
A characteristic of arrangement which refers to its related arrangements.

An exposed function (an externalized functionality) that is able to deliver a certain value/benefit (a proposed definition adapted from Archimate).
A unit of functionality that a system exposes to its environment, while hiding internal operations, which provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise).
Comment:
A Service is something that is done by an actor for the benefit of an actor in the environment.
A system is the broad sense of the word. Means Business Service, Application Service, Technology Service, "huppeldepup" Service
Characteristics of a service:
A system (The Service Domain) Functionality is exposed (Action Term) It provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise)
Exposing functionality means that the internals of realizing the service is hidden for the beneficiary of the Service.
In BIAN a "Service Operation" is visualized as a "Business Service" , the "System" refers to the "Service Domain"
The name of a Service Operation is composed of an "Action Term" + "Subject Matter" which is the "Control Record" or the "Behaviour Qualifier".
Service is the intangible equivalent of a good. (ISO20022).
A type of economic activity that is intangible, is not stored and does not result in ownership; a service is consumed at the point of sale (FIBO & Business Dictionary)
The way in which a service can happen.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
The definition of an addressable space/position both in real and virtual environments with associated uses and entitlements
A pathway established via a communication medium. A contact point by which the bank interacts with parties.
The involvement (role) of an instance of a party in an instance of a product.
A Physical or virtual space where buyers, sellers, market authorities and other market parties trade products and services according to market rules.
the rating/certification derived as result of an applied test assessment of an entity using specific testing criteria
A set of rules (e.g., regulation, policy, law, guideline, principle, standard) to guide, direct or operate a subject matter.
Jurisdiction that will be assigned in case of legal dispute.
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.

A party represents an autonomous entity in which a bank has a business interest. It has a legal definition and identity. A party is a Person, Organization, (a proposed definition for BIAN BOM adapted from BIAN Party Working Group)
- Entity involved in an activity. (ISO20022)

An interface through which parties can communicate or exchange goods or services.
Comment: A channel can be internal or external. Channel identifies the different delivery and communications mechanisms through which products, and services are made available to parties and by which the parties communicate with each other.
Examples: Shop, a web shop, email, television screens in the shops, servicedesk, e-mail, phone, …
A product feature which is a restriction on (the size or amount or value of ) something.
An arrangement to limit something e.g., the number of transaction per week, the amount of money allowed to withdraw per week/day and etc.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
Specification of how a limit arrangement can be applied.
A Service Arrangement promissed to deliver Cash Management Account Service.

An arrangement into which is promised to deliver a specific service.
Comment: Most service arrangements are instantiations of Product Services

A measuring state on which movements in value or amounts of assets, rights and obligations are registered.
Comment: It is a bookkeeping instrument holding the amount or value of something by registering the movements in plus and min when events happen which have an impact on the position. The term "account" is usually associated to an accounting or bookkeeping concept to hold the financial or stock state of a business concept. An account will typically group the debit and credit entries for a specific aspect of the business resulting from transactions, Often accounts are represented as a T-account which is a visual aid used to depict an account. Above the top portion of the T would be the account title. On the left-side of the base of the T would be any debit amounts; on the right-side would be the credit amounts. A commonly used bookkeeping method is the double-entry method. This means that every transaction has at least 2 movements. If a customer pays 100 € in cash, there is a decrease in the amount that the customer owes to the company (the customer position is decreased) an increase in the amount that the company has in cash (the cash position is increased)
An account can be assigning to one or more ledgers. A ledger is a group of accounts for a certain purpose. If there is need for multiple ledgers because of multiple purpose, an account can perfectly well assigned to multiple ledgers. When Ledgers are in real physical books, this is not possible. When ledgers are digital, accounts can be grouped into multiple groups at the same time. This practice is very rarely taught into courses for accounting, but in digital accounting, it is common practice.
Examples: stock account of a shop, cash register, bank account, financial accounting account, customer account, supplier account, ... Bank Account BE12 1234 5678 9012: is an individual banking account Accounts Payable, is a collective account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to its suppliers. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to suppliers. This account is managed usually in a General Ledger Supplier Account X, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts to pay by the organisation to an individual supplier. The balance is the result of the financial movements related to an individual supplier. This account is managed usually in a sub-ledger. Stock Account x, is an individual account keeping the balance of the amounts in stock of a specific good. A payment service to take fund out of an account.
A characteristic of account which refers to the LifecycleStatus of account like opened, closed, blocked, etc.
The identifier of account like Account Number.
A characteristic of account which refers to LifecycleDate of account (e.g., ClosingDate, OpeningDate, LiveDate, etc.)
Specifies the category of account like payment account, loan account, cash account, securities account, etc.

The state of the obligations managed on the account, the result of all entries on the account.
Numerical representation of the net increases and decreases in an account at a specific point in time. (ISO20022)
Banking: Amount available in an account for withdrawal or use. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html
Bookkeeping: Difference between the debit and credit sides of an account. Read more: http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/balance.html
A detailed explanation or commentary of account.
The fulfilment of the engagements (obligations/rights) taken in an arrangement
Something that happens, has happened, can happen or is planned to happen.

A contract that gives rise to a financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity instrument of another entity. (IFRS) https://www.iasplus.com/en/standards/ias/ias32#:~:text=Key%20definitions%20%5BIAS%2032.11%5D,equity%20instrument%20of%20another%20entity
Financial instruments are financial contracts of different nature made between institutional units. These comprise the full range of financial claims and liabilities between institutional units, including contingent liabilities like guarantees, commitments, etc. (ISO 10962)
A record of events/entries.
A specific role of a specific Party in the specific relationship.
A transaction that changes the financial position (the status of the finances) of involved party.

A planned or performed action in the context of concluding or fulfilling an agreement.
Act to do something.
An instruction to do something expressed in an amount of money.
A request to do something.
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a loan account agreement.
An arrangement defining the applicable features for a Corporate Deposit Agreement.

An arrangement defining the applicable features for a savings account agreement.
The arrangement type is one of those possible/mandatory for the sale of a savings account product. The actual arrangements are a selection of those offered under the savings account product.
a distinctive attribute or aspect of something.

An exposed function (an externalized functionality) that is able to deliver a certain value/benefit (a proposed definition adapted from Archimate).
A unit of functionality that a system exposes to its environment, while hiding internal operations, which provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise).
Comment:
A Service is something that is done by an actor for the benefit of an actor in the environment.
A system is the broad sense of the word. Means Business Service, Application Service, Technology Service, "huppeldepup" Service
Characteristics of a service:
A system (The Service Domain) Functionality is exposed (Action Term) It provides a certain value (monetary or otherwise)
Exposing functionality means that the internals of realizing the service is hidden for the beneficiary of the Service.
In BIAN a "Service Operation" is visualized as a "Business Service" , the "System" refers to the "Service Domain"
The name of a Service Operation is composed of an "Action Term" + "Subject Matter" which is the "Control Record" or the "Behaviour Qualifier".
Service is the intangible equivalent of a good. (ISO20022).
A type of economic activity that is intangible, is not stored and does not result in ownership; a service is consumed at the point of sale (FIBO & Business Dictionary)
An subject matter about which arrangements should or can be made when selling a savings account product.
A duty that is specified in and imposed by an agreement. (FIBO)

An event related to the behaviour performed by an actor.
Comment: An actor can be a party or a machine An action Includes various types of requests, orders and financial transactions. Includes responses where appropriate. An action is an event which means that the concept describes the result of acting.
An agreement established among the card holder and the card issuer to use the payment card for payment
Arrangement whitin the product sales agreement
A Feature Modality applicable to a Product Feature
Posting events to the log.
ServiceArrangement defined for cash financial instruments like FeeArrangement, DepositArrangement, ...
structure/make-up of an organizational entity
The way in which a feature can happen. Feature can be a Service or Condition
Set of integrated applications that provides centralised services such as clearing, netting, reconciliation, trading and/or settlement. (ISO20022)

An interface through which parties can communicate or exchange goods or services.
Comment: A channel can be internal or external. Channel identifies the different delivery and communications mechanisms through which products, and services are made available to parties and by which the parties communicate with each other.
Examples: Shop, a web shop, email, television screens in the shops, servicedesk, e-mail, phone, …
An arrangement within the product sales agreement
A Product Service that combines services and features that are similar to checking, savings and/or investment accounts under one product.
An arrangement which specifies to charge fees when banking transactions did take place, accompanied by the modalities to calculate and charge the fees and the related terms and conditions.
Specifies the type of fee which is applicable to the amount of goods/services. (ISO20022)
Base amount that would be applied when the service is requested.
Rate used to calculate the amount of the adjustment, allowance, charge or fee. (ISO20022)
Period during which the fee is applicable. (ISO20022)
Date on which the fee needs to be paid. - It is not nessessary a date and could be expressed as a calander or formula or events that would be fulfiled.
An arranged FeeRatePlan

A cash management account is a brokerage account designed for managing cash, making payments, and earning interest. A cash management account (CMA) combines many of the best aspects of checking and savings accounts.
An service arrangement which specifies the acceptance of withdrawals, accompanied by the modalities to withdraw money.
The type of withdrawal transaction that can be applied to the account (e.g. customer withdrawal, internal service charge, disbursement)
Handling options in case a withdrawal results in exceeding the agreed limit
ServiceArrangement defined for non-cash financial instruments like SecuritiesDepositArrangement, ...

An arrangement that grants a creditor the right to use an asset as a guarantee for an underlying obligation.
A lien is a legal right granted by the owner of property, by a law or otherwise acquired by a creditor. A lien serves to guarantee an underlying obligation, such as the repayment of a loan. If the underlying obligation is not satisfied, the creditor may be able to seize the asset that is the subject of the lien. (Investopedia)
A lien is a legal document filed by a creditor (lender) in order to record its claim on the debtor's (borrower's) property. The lien is recorded at a government's office. The lien provides a creditor with some protection or collateral until the debtor pays the creditor the amount owed. (Accounting Coach)
A legal claim against an asset which is used to secure a loan and which must be paid when the property is sold. Liens can be structured in many different ways. In some cases, the creditor will have legal claim against an asset, but not actually hold it in possession, while in other cases the creditor will actually hold on to the asset until the debt is paid off. The former is a more common arrangement when the asset is productive, since the creditor would prefer that the asset be used to produce a stream of income to pay off debt rather than just held in possession and not used. A claim can hold against an asset until all the obligations to the creditor are cleared (a general lien), or just until the obligations against that particular assets are cleared (a particular lien). (Investorword)
Difference between Lien and Collateral? The Lien is the agreement, the Collateral is the asset. So, a collateral agreement and a lien are synonyms. see also https://efinancemanagement.com/sources-of-finance/pledge-vs-hypothecation-vs-lien-vs-mortgage-vs-assignment
The type of Lien
The party requesting the lien.

The reason why the lien is taken.
Should refer to another agreements arrangement whose obligations are guaranteed by the lien
The amount being blocked.
The date the lien is enforced.
The date the lien is removed.
The status on the lien.
Processing guidelines

Reference to the subject the lean is placed upon
e.g. the savings account the lien is placed upon
Parameters to be used in the lien modalities

Arrangement in which funds are transferred from one deposit account to another when a certain threshold is reached.
Banking arrangement in which a checking (current) account balance above or below a certain amount is automatically transferred to and from an interest-bearing (savings or money market fund) account. The objective of a sweep account is to maximize the accountholder's interest earnings while covering all withdrawals. (Business Dictionary)
Sweep Account is a brokerage account whose cash balance is automatically transferred into an interest-bearing investment, such as a money market fund. (Investorwords)
The type of sweep (e.g. periodic, threshold).

The way sweep transactions will be triggered and executed (on the "from side) or what the reaction should be (on the receive side)
e.g. buy securities when a sweep of the "petty cash" type is received on a securities account from a current account
Reference to the account the funds are transferred to or from
Timing and or triggers for initiating sweep transaction;
Permission to define a sweep arrangement to the target account.
Indication whether the savings account is source or target of the sweep arrangement
An arrangement into which both parties confirm on an interest product feature.
Specifies the type of interest associated with a trade. (ISO20022)

An arranged InterestRate
InterestRate: A price generally expressed as a percentage for the use of capital unit for a certain period
Specifies the type of rate used to calculate the interest. (ISO20022)
Period during which the interest rate has to be applied.
An arranged InterestRatePlan

An service arrangement which specifies the acceptance of deposits, accompanied by the modalities to deposit money.
An arrangement in which a lender gives money or property to a borrower, and the borrower agrees to return the property or repay the money, usually along with interest, at some future point(s) in time. (ISO20022)
The type of deposit transaction that can be applied to the account (e.g. customer deposit, internal credit, funding, ...)

A limit imposed to the facility to deposit funds
e.g. minimum deposit of 500€, maximum of 5000 per year, maximum balance of 500 000€This is the actual "value" that has to be used in "the algorithm depicted by the "type".

Type of limit imposed on a deposit facility
e.g. maximum amount per deposit or per periodThis is "the algorithm"
An arrangement which specifies the promise to offer the payment service, accompanied by the payment modalities.
Due date for the payment. (ISO20022)
Period to which the payment terms apply. (ISO20022)
Date at which the arrangement/obligation will expire. (ISO20022)
An even that triggers the fulfilment of a fee arrangement.

Amount of fee that is charged.
Amount of money that results from the application of an adjustment (charges. fees, discount or allowance) to the amount due. (ISO20022)
Date on which the fee needs to be paid.
Information about the fee transaction, such as reason, period, applied formula...

A selection of interest product feature modalities for a specific interestment arrangement in a specific agreemen
The specification of the set of parameters used to calculate an interest amount. (adapted from ISO20022)
A method has to be used for calculating the interest
The periodicity of the calculation of the interest. (ISO20022)
The calculation date of the interest amount. (ISO20022)
A parameter used to calculate the interest

Specifies whether the interest calculation method is simple or compounding. (ISO20022)
Simple: Calculation method by which interest is calculated on the original principal only. Accumulated interest from prior periods is not used in calculations for the following periods. (ISO20022)
Compounding: Calculation method by which interest is calculated each period on the original principal and all interest accumulated during past periods. (ISO20022)
A fulfillment of a specific interest arrangement
The amount of interest that is subject of this transaction
The InterestType of the Interest arrangement this is a transaction for
Interest amount that has accrued in between coupon payment periods. (ISO20022)
The date on which the interest has to be payed
Description of the transaction, such as applied interest rate, Interest period ...
The instruction concerning to take money from an account.

Reference to how, by whom and in what "materialisation" the withdrawal is performed.
e.g. as a bank cheque, in cash
Type of the withdrawal e.g. reservation, actual withdrawal ???
Information about the purpose or other reference information accompanying the withdrawal.
The withdrawn sum.
The Date(time) on which the withdrawal is initiated.

A financial instruction to fulfill a deposit service arrangement.
An instruction to place money on an account.

Reference to how, by whom and in what "materialization" the deposit is performed?
e.g. by cheque, in cash

Type of deposit
e.g. conditional awaiting confirmation of a cheque
Information about the purpose or other reference information accompanying the deposit
the deposited sum
The Date"time) on which the deposit is initiated
Instruction to pay an amount of money to an ultimate beneficiary, on behalf of an originator. (ISO20022)
Execution of the sweep arrangement
The account in which the sweep amount came from or went to
The date on which the sweep transfer was executed
Instruction to execute a payment from a payer to a payee

Classification of the Money Transfer Instruction according to the event that lead to the instruction
e.g. withdrawal, interest disbursement, direct debit, card payment.
Amount of money to be transferred.
Currency in which the transfer amount is expressed.

The reason why the instruction is given
can be reference to a lot of information, concerning e.g. a purchase, an arrangement fulfillment event, a billing period...
The network to be used for the processing of the money transfer instruction as requested in the instruction. e.g. instant SEPA?
The processing status of the instruction
Reference to the contact channel that was used to give the money transfer instruction
Transfer of money between two parties and/or accounts
The amount of money transferred from the source to the target.
The currency of the money transfer amount
The account the money is transferred from.
The account the money is transferred to.
The method used to transfer money; Can be a payment network but also something physical.
The date on which the money is considerd to have left/have arrived become active can be used /strats to starts is considerd to be
An agreed commitment to perform actions that meet obligations under an agreement
A status which refers to the LifecycleStatus of arrangement (e.g., requested, proposed, offered, accepted, cancelled, terminated, fulfilled, etc.);
A package of services and goods, accompanied by term and condition which is offered as a whole to (internal or external) customers.
The identifier of product e.g. ISIN Code.
Specifies the category/type/class of product like financial product. Product can be categorized according to different perspectives.
Refers to the lifecycle of a product (e.g., initiated, announced, active, obsolete, withdrawn).
A detailed explanation or commentary of product.
A service offered as a feature of a product.
A detailed characteristic of a product expressed in offered services and the terms and conditions applicable to the delivery of the services.
The type or category of product/service features
An arrangement to limit something e.g., the number of transaction per week, the amount of money allowed to withdraw per week/day and etc.
Period at which the limit is effective. (ISO20022)
Amount of money of the limit, expressed in a currency. (ISO20022)
THe status of Limit e.g., Enabled, Disabled, Deleted and Requested.
